titlestmt.subtitle: Papers of Harlow S. Webster, 1831-1901, at the Lilly Library, Indiana University
titlestmt.author: Alyssa Mertka

note.p: Trustees of Indiana University. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-02-18 22:23:22 -0500.

did.abstract: The Webster mss., 1831-1901, consists primarily of the family correspondence and diaries of Harlow S. Webster, 1815-1902, of LaPorte County, Indiana.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Many collections are housed offsite; retrieval requires advance notice. Please make an appointment a minimum of one week in advance of your visit.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Photography and digitization may be restricted for some collections. Copyright restrictions may apply. Before publishing, researchers are responsible for securing permission from all applicable rights holders, then filling out the Permission to Publish form.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Harlow Sharp Webster, 1815-1902, was a farmer who lived in Indiana and Iowa. He was born on March 15, 1815 in Locke, New York. On November 10, 1842, he married Mary June (Black) Webster, 1824-1895, who was the daughter of Eli and Mary Black. They lived in La Porte County, Indiana and had three children: Ellen Mary Webster, 1843-1844; Alice Mary Webster, 1846-1865; and Calista Webster, 1848-1933. Later in his life, Webster moved to Howard County, Iowa where he worked as a farmer. He died on May 18, 1902 and is buried in Cresco, Howard County, Iowa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Webster mss., 1831-1901, consist primarily of family correspondence, 1831-1893, and of the diaries of Harlow S. Webster of LaPorte County, Indiana, for the years 1854-1901. The Webster mss. consists primarily of family correspondence, 1831-1893, and of the diaries of Harlow S. Webster for the years 1854-1901.

Correspondents include Mary June (Black) Webster's parents and siblings, as well as the Webster children. The topics of discussion tend to dwell on family matters and day-to-day life. A particularly interesting group of letters are those from Calista Webster to her parents in June 1893 when she and her family were visiting the World's Columbian Exhibition in Chicago. These nine letters provide a detailed report on the events, displays, foods, and general activities of the Fair.

Harlow Webster's diaries, beginning in 1854 and lacking only 1858, provide a daily report of the weather, growing conditions, and the activities of the Webster family and acquaintances. Entries are less full in the last few volumes, when illness and pain prevented Webster from writing.
A few undated miscellaneous items and three unidentified photographs complete the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged following original order.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Webster mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.
